course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Business Modeling and Optimization
course.description: The science and technology of informed decision making with focus on optimizing business processes. Spreadsheet decision modeling in Excel will be used throughout. Emphasis on problem formulation, spreadsheet-based solution methods, and managerial insights. Applications to managerial decision problems in diverse industries and functional areas including finance and accounting, human resource, marketing, and operations.
course.exclusions: CIVL 2170, IEDA 3010, PHYS 4059

reviews.author: xin1
reviews.title: A very useful hands-on course with good grade and relative light workload
reviews.comment_content:
Focus on modeling and problem solving using Excel. The emphasis will be on building useful models for analyzing and solving practical problems. Many useful Excel shortcuts and tips would also be taught.
Sometimes it would be a little troublesome for Mac users but it won't affect quiz and exam.

Contents
• Ch 2: Introduction to spreadsheet modeling
• Ch 3: Introduction to optimization modeling
• Ch 4: Linear Programming models
• Ch 5: Network models
• Ch 6: Optimization models with integer variables
• Ch 7: Nonlinear optimization models
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof ZHENG would mainly demonstrate how to solve the problem on Excel with PPT slides. And he would do some revision at the beginning of each lecture. His teaching is very clear and concise, and he's willing to answer any question or repeat the demon if requested.
Very slight accent which affects nothing, the speed is a little bit slow for me ( I always watch the lecture recording at 1.5x or 2x speed)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading very goods I think.
Grading scheme:
• Quiz (in-class): 20% (1h20min, On Canvas, all questions will be displayed on one page, a simple format Excel file will be provided for each question, and upload the finished Excel file, relatively easy);
• Homework: 30% (4 group assignments completed within a group of up to 3);
• Final examination: 40% (2h50min, Same as the quiz, but much harder, Prof said it's normal if we can't finish all questions, it's designed this way) ;
• Class Attendance: 10% (attendance will be counted only if the student attended the class for at least half of the time (i.e., 40 minutes), will get full mark if miss no more than 2 lectures);
• Bonus point for class participation/discussion.

Statistics:
• Homework: almost everyone gets full mark;
• Quiz: Mean: 89.4 High: 100 Low: 0
• Final: Mean: 77.1 High: 105 Low: 30 (out of 112) Sd:13.8
• Attendance: Mean: 8.3 High: 10 Low: 0

Me:
• Homework: 38/40
• Quiz: 91/100
• Final: 83/112
• Attendance: 10/10
• No bonus point
Finally got A-, really good grade (Thanks Professor!). I thought I'd get B or B+ since I'm slightly above mean for everything. Don't know how he exactly gives letter grade since there were 2 sections this semester.
reviews.comment_workload: Surprisingly light workload for a 4-credit course! Each group homework could be completed within 2-4 hours.

reviews.author: Caroline
reviews.title: unexpectedly good grade course
reviews.comment_content: Basically building profit maximizing or cost minimizing models under different conditions using Excel. Some useful techniques for Excel would be taught like arranging roosters, transportation models, investment models.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He taught using PowerPoint and excel files.He spoke clearly though a little bit too fast. Just follow his every step to do the classwork and print the excel files out. Do remember to do the exercise he listed from the textbook. Some might appear in the exam. You will be fine even you are a newbie to excel.
For tutorial, no need to go. They just repeat some skills from class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance  6%

Homework 10%
full mark (mean is usually 95+)

Quiz 20%
100/100 (mean:89.5) basically most people get full mark

Final  64%
62.5/100 (mean: 75.2)

I thought I would get a C range
but finally I get B!!!
Thank you professor!!
reviews.comment_workload:
open book exam
your only workload are attend lessons, do exercise he listed, print some useful classwork before exam.

reviews.author: 維他冇奶
reviews.comment_content:
Solver Solver Solver and Solver
90% 堂都係教你用solver
總之就係比D constraint 你再叫你搵optimal solution
reviews.comment_teaching:
教得幾清晰, 每堂都有example
d quiz final 反而係考你有冇sense
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good grade.
40% (2 out of 3 quiz) , 60% final
Quiz 1: 50/100 Mean: 72.8 /100
Quiz 2: 70/100 Mean: 67.1/100
Quiz 3: 100/100 Mean: 79.7/100
Final: 87/100 Mean: 78.7/100
Grade A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Very Very light workload as a 4 credit course :D
Only quiz and final , no assignment, no group project
but count parti. (if u miss too many class, mark will be deducted)

reviews.author: Avocado
reviews.title: Very hands-on and useful.
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly focuses on optimisation, problem solving and decision making. Rather than focusing specific theories or frameworks (like you would encounter in most of the other courses), the professor introduces various problems each class, and the class time is spent in thinking about how to solve these problems logically, and then using Excel (and related Excel functions like Solver) to solve these problems.

For people who like studying out a textbook with a clear syllabus and topic list, I think this course will be quite interesting (and challenging) in the beginning, since there are no lecture notes provided, per say.

The content itself is very interesting, and you get to learn a lot about different Excel features and functions (I certainly learnt a lot of useful functions). A lot of the things you learn can be applied in various other courses, like workforce scheduling, production optimisation, logistics, etc.

As a required course for the OM major, I would definitely say that the course is quite fascinating, practical and useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Zhang is a very friendly and helpful professor, and he's very willing to answer any questions you may have (through email or face-to-face). Initially, you might find the style of teaching a bit different, as you spend the entire lesson going through 4-5 Excel files and solving various problems. If you can get used to this style of learning, then I find that you will definitely be able to appreciate Prof. Zhang's teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is relatively fair.

The final grade is made up of two major components
— Quizzes (3 quizzes, 15% each)
— Final Exam (55%)

The quizzes are held in-class and contain relatively short problems (it's hard to predict what the problems will be).

The final exam is much tougher and requires much more thinking, and it can cover anything taught in the course.

You can skip all of the quizzes and shift the entire weighting of the course to the final exam, the professor is very flexible with this.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload really depends on the grade you want. There are no homework assignments or projects due. The professor does upload 3 exercises (for the whole semester), but these are optional - although it's a good idea to complete these exercises since they are a good way to practice your skills.

reviews.author: tsa
reviews.comment_content:
Useful
it teaches the constrained optimisation and decision making which are very useful in the business operations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
quite boring
the instructor was late for class sometimes.
The TA is not very helpful sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading:
reasonable
the mean for the course is quite high ie. around 80-90 percent.
the exam questions are mostly coming from the assignment and examples from class. So, it is extremely important to finish them all before exam and mid-term.
reviews.comment_workload:
reasonable
there are two mid-exam and one final exam accouting for 60 percent. There are assignments assigned by the instructor but they are not mandatory.

reviews.author: Christyhooo
reviews.comment_content: The content is not hard to understand and the professor will repeat the steps for several time. But I think it is still hard to do the questions by myself lol.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is good, and he is very willing to answer questions and he will repeat every steps for few times.
reviews.comment_grading: I am not sure about the grading cuz I got low marks in the quiz and exam lol.
reviews.comment_workload: have quizzes and final exam, but no homework so the workload is not huge. But need spend time to review the course material yourself.

reviews.author: KYkabstaaaar
reviews.comment_content:
Pretty direct and useful Excel skills, including Excel solver (throughout the whole semester), basic functions and the most commonly used functions: data pivot and vlookup in the future working situations.

Excel solver was required to used to find optimal solutions under different circumstances, and the content became harder at the end.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Hong Tao is sincere and fun, he tried to conduct something different from the teaching contents at the end of several lectures, like speaking Excel……

He was also looking forward of students' participation during the lectures and he even launch the optional grading system after finding out lots of students were worrying about their grade after the first quiz (cuz it was quite tricky), overall, Hong Tao is nice!
reviews.comment_grading:
2 quizes (20% each)
1 final exam （60%）
Try to get as high as possible in the two quizs because the final exam is totally on the next level of difficulty.
All the excel docs would be provided during both quizs and final exam for references.

My grade:
Quiz 1:Full mark
Quiz 2: Just bove mean
Final exam: close to full mark
My final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
If you can be concentrated on every single lecture or you can get the contents of each lecture, it would not take you any other spare time as there is zero homework for this course.

For the quizs and final exam revision, download all the lecture questions and execercise questions and go through them all again, then you should be fine.

reviews.author: KaneKayn
reviews.comment_content: quite fun, about excel solver, use to find optimal solution under different scenario. Very basic but useful excel functions like sumifs will be covered in this course. IF you are not an expert in excel these basics would be very helpful as well when you encounter excel later in your life (which you will)
reviews.comment_teaching: coach hongtao is kinda a fun guy, often makes some jokes. He teaches quite well and clearly. I will say his teaching is fast paced tho but as long as you pay attention you wont fall behind
reviews.comment_grading:
grading is nice I suppose but as this course is easy it means its not easy to get A range. Make some mistakes and you are done. BTW the exam is quite difficult so make sure you get prepared for it

2 quizzes (20% each), 1 exam (60%)
Quiz 1: 98/100
Quiz 2: 100/100
Exam: 71/100 (bruh)
Final grade: B+
SO YEAH DONT MESS UP UR EXAM!!!
reviews.comment_workload: no, except doing tutorial questions yourself for your own good

reviews.author: KaruizawaKei
reviews.title: Head Coach Hongtao is the best
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic excel functions, formula, and solver
Like:
Average, min, max, percentile, sumproduct, sumifs, countifs...

Also, some techniques in excel like the usage of logical bound.
reviews.comment_teaching: Excellent teaching. Professor ZHANG is humorous and nice. He is easy-going and willing to answer questions whatever we raised.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very lenient!
Quiz 1 (20%)
Quiz 2 (20%)
Final (60%)
If your performance is not good in quizzes, the proportion will be shifted to the final.

Also, there will be random attendance checking, all of us have 3 quotas. 1 mark will be deducted from total if he found you skipped more than 3 lectures.
reviews.comment_workload: 0 workload. No assignments, no homework, only attendance. The best, most relaxed course ever in HKUST.

reviews.author: Klay12
reviews.title: ISOM3710 Coach Zhang
reviews.comment_content:
# Useful and handful excel stuff including common excel functions and excel solver

# Applications to solving managerial decision problems in diverse industries and functional areas will be discussed, including
- Operations Management: logistics and supply chains management; airline flight scheduling; airline hub location; process flow management.
- Finance and accounting: breakeven analysis; investment analysis; loan portfolio planning; pension fund planning; portfolio selection.
- Human resources: workforce scheduling; sales territory assignment and sales-force allocation.
- Marketing: allocating marketing expenditures; retail pricing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
# Coach Zhang is passionate and willing to answer any question you encounter. He is able to explain everything clearly by using some decent examples.

# Not traditional powerpoint reader because he only go through and solve the excel problems in class.

# No comments for tutorial classes since I did not attend.
reviews.comment_grading:
# Two Quizzes, 20% each; Final 60%

# You cannot miss more than three classes after add-drop period, even though there is no attendance component. 1 mark will be deducted for exceeding the upper bound.

# If you do better on the final exam than on the quiz, he will shift the weight of each quiz, 20%, to the final exam. Therefore, the weight of final exam could be 80% or 100% as well. However, in general the average exam score will be lower than the average quiz score.

# There are FIVE questions in the final exam, 20 points each. The below is the knowledge or skills covered in each question (Can't remember all the details):
1. Basic Excel function
- Data Validation
- INDEX(), MATCH()
- Absolute reference, Relative reference
- CORREL(),COVARIANCE.P()
2. Random Sequence
- RAND(), RANK()
- COUNTIFS()
- How to create a data-table with 1000 samples
3-5. Excel solver with three different levels
- Easy: Basic constraints type
- Intermediate: Cumulative demand and supply
- Difficult: Logical bounds and multiple changing variables. For this one, I still don't know how to quickly think of the solution to this type of problem.

FYI:
Quiz 1: 68/100 (0%)
Quiz 2: 100/100 (20%)
Final Exam: 94/100 (80%)
Overall Score: 95.2/100
Grade: A
"I don’t publish summary stats – they have nothing to do with learning." —— Prof. Zhang
reviews.comment_workload:
# Light, No homework and assignment.

# Suggestion: Do all the lecture examples from scratch and exercises provided before quizzes and final exam!!!

reviews.author: Hayoha
reviews.comment_content:
Textbook: Practical  Management  Science,  6th  edition,  by  Winston  and  Albright,  Cengage,  
2019.
Ch 2: Introduction to spreadsheet modeling
Ch 3: Introduction to optimization modeling
Ch 4: Linear Programming models
Ch 5: Network models
Ch 6: Optimization models with integer variables
Ch 7: Nonlinear optimization models
reviews.comment_teaching:
Well-prepared PPTs, explain the concepts with good examples, Professor Zheng is kind to give time for us to practice during classes.

He does not like people chatting during lecture, or looking at smartphone, if you chat with your classmate, he will stop and walk toward you, OR he just let you realize the silence in the class and everyone looking at you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz (Midterm) 20%
Homework 25%
Final Exam 45%
Class Attendance 10%

Quiz: 83/100, Mean 88.3, upper quartile: 99, SD: 11.94

HW1: 9.5/10 Mean: 9.7
HW2: 10/10 Mean: 9.5
HW3: 8.5/10 Mean: 9.5
HW4:  10/10 Mean: 9.7

Class attendance: I think I just sign my name for 5 times (around), so I guess there are 5% for answering questions, but I did not.
Final: 81/100, Mean: 65.75, Median: 68, Std: 20.10167
I think good grade la, as I only expect myself get B, but at last B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework is done by group (up to 3 people). If you are lucky to get great group members to carry you, it is not heavy in term of wrokload, but they are difficult. I have sent emails to ask TAs but they probably can't help with homeworks. So bless yourself is clever enough to set up the correct solver/ your group members are excellent. You can also choose to group by yourself only so no need to share your hardwork with others (If you are confident).

Heard the rumors about searching answers/ buying sources, so the mean is super high.

Midterm is easy (I am so stupid), basically just the examples from lectures, Professor allowed open book, open notes and can bring laptop.

Final is more difficult, and no laptop this time. There are only PPTs in the lab room computers (in Midterm, the templates and finished examples from lectures are still provided).
For final, I think the effort of working on book exercises should be helpful.

reviews.comment_content:
Desc: Scientific approach to informed decision making and managerial problem solving. Spreadsheet modeling in
Excel. The central modeling framework is constrained optimization. Emphases on model building and solution
interpretation. Extensive hands‐on exercises. Exposure to a wide variety of managerial problems.

Basically excel stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Decent examples and really tries to interest you in using excel and learning the excel solver stuff.
Even if you aren't really well versed in excel, you could watch the videos back and ask questions in tutorial sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 quizzes best 2 out of 3- 20% for each, total of 40% watching the videos back was usually good enough for the quizzes.
final exam -60%
attendance only allowed for 3 or 4 skips. this was during online schooling so I afk'd all lessons anyways though
reviews.comment_workload:
In-class exercises
3 quizzes
Final exam
Overall, not too much work considering its 4 credits.
also recommend doing the exercises that are sometimes shown in tutorial

reviews.author: Colliiiii
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting in total. some simple numerical learing and caculation. As a pre-enroll calss for some major, it`s quite easy to handle.
Regular tool is just excel and you can do all the hw and exams by using that. Course`s content is designed to fufill those who may not know how to use these tools but in total the teaching progress is fine.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is fine though professor may sudenlly ask someone for question.
Professsor says everything clearly. You will know how to do better in the learing progress. Also, He is open to any questions. You can send emails anytime if you have any questions though it may not be replied at once. Due to the online teaching, I don`t know what it will be in real class but as the professor is good I don`t think it will be a bad experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
midterm: 1sd above mean
final: 1.5sd above mean
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
little workload. Yoou can spend 2-3 days before exam days and get an A range. Really satisfying.
Hw is also easy to handle. Youmay just use excel to solve the question in one hour.

reviews.author: jklm
reviews.comment_content: Basically an Excel course. It is useful and practical. Not related to ISOM2700.
reviews.comment_teaching: He explains everything well. He usually repeats the steps and make sure everyone can follow (sometimes you feel bored if you are smart enough to finish the task by yourself). There is a 5-mins break in the middle of the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 quiz, 1 final exam in total

only 2 quiz will be counted into your grade (drop 1 quiz) - 40%
3 questions in 1 quiz. The questions are not difficult, similar to/same with those you worked on during lesson.

final exam - 60%
6 questions in total. I think it's much harder than the quizzes and in-class exercises.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment. Attendance is required, which maybe the most difficult part in this course as the lessons start at 9am. Understanding the in-class exercise will be enough for the quizzes and exam.

reviews.author: Rossi
reviews.comment_content:
This lecture will give you more idea and logic on how to simplify and optimize a model by using excel. You will learn a lot of formula, how to use solver and other functions in excel such as conditional formatting, naming,  pivot table... These are some most common used functions during the lecture.
-sumifs
-sumproduct
-index
-match

I would say these skills are very useful for logistic and data analysis. The course is using big data to make decision. Even though some of the models maybe too specific that unusual for the authentic business field, you will still much familiar with excel and it is a very great skill inside the industry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Every lecture the prof will give student 1-2 excel files, sometimes 3,  included the problems and format inside. Then the prof will give you some time to figure it out first then he will show you the answer step by step. I was having zoom lecture at that time, he might think that we are lack of interaction, and he will directly ask a specific person to answer some questions. I don't know whether he will do the same in offline lecture. I recommend to review his recording since sometimes he goes through stuff a bit too fast. Also, he will tell some jokes that are not funny but we just pretend it was.  Yet, overall his teaching is very logical and detail and he is indeed a great prof. that willing to listen and answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
-3 quiz (40%)
-1 final exam (60%)

The prof. will only choose 2 highest scored out of 3 quiz so you could skip one (i did so). The score of the whole class is basically high. The mean was always like 70-80 something. I got most of them on mean in the quiz and a bit below mean in the final. Yet, I got B+ at the end. I think the grading is great.
reviews.comment_workload: You have 3 chances to absent otherwise he will deduct some of your marks. There is no midterm yet Quiz 2 is almost near the midterm so the timing may not that good. But this course does not have homework or project. The only thing is sometimes you may not catch up the lecture since he thought you already familiar with the functions. It's great overall.

reviews.author: Alice.C
reviews.title: Helpful and easy course
reviews.comment_content:
Basically all excel work
- conditional formatting
- what-if analysis
reviews.comment_teaching: He speaks fluent English and very approachable. He answers all the doubts and questions nicely and replies pretty fast to emails. His teaching style is very clear and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is quite fair and I would even say it is pretty good. I was above mean for all the quizzes and final exam so expecting B+ or A- and I think I got A- so its fair.

I got 100/100 and 90/100 for the quiz
And 80/100 for final
reviews.comment_workload: Surprisingly very light considering that it is a 4 credit course. Only quiz and final exam to prepare and even that, just go through the notes from class and the questions are do-able.

reviews.author: ongb
reviews.title: You need to be an expert of Excel
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly learning Excel during the lesson
No Powerpoint will be given
Excel solver, pivot table, basic excel skill will be learn
I think kinda like we need to answer some IQ questions using Excel
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is very nice, called himself as a 'Coach'
Even though only 5 people attend the online lesson, he still pays effort to teach
Tutorial is quite boring, usually within 30 mins
reviews.comment_grading:
40% Quiz (Count 2 out of 3)
60% Exam
Unless you perform well in exam, you won't get a good grade
However, the exam is totally different from the quizzes
10 times harder
reviews.comment_workload:
No assessment but only quiz
Quite chill~

reviews.author: Oscarrrrr
reviews.title: Useful
reviews.comment_content: Learn how to build vary models to solve operating problems by using excel. It is practical and useful for OM students to apply this skill in future career.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is slow and usually makes mistakes...
It is more efficient if you watch the lecture videos in 2X speed than attending to his class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 10%
Midterm 25%
Final 65%

Final does matter!! Review all sample questions and hw before the exam. The grading is quite good that I got everything slightly below mean, but I still got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments take you some time to finish it. Building excel models is a bit time-consuming if you are not familiar with the examples he teaches in classes.

Generally the workload is light. Just make sure you understand what he teaches.

reviews.author: ryan.hyh
reviews.comment_content:
Required Course for OM Major, it is not difficult, basically just Excel. Easy to get high marks if you attend all his lectures, tutorials are not necessary.

Ch 1, 2: Introduction to spreadsheet modeling
Ch 3: Introduction to optimization modeling
Ch 4: Linear Programming
Ch 5: Network models
Ch 6: Optimization models with integer variables
Ch 7: Nonlinear optimization models
reviews.comment_teaching: Every lesson is just solving 2-3 questions using Excel. He is boring, slow pace, always make mistakes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Homework: 10%
Midterm: 25%
Final examination: 65%;
Bonus (based on your class participation): 3%

Final course scores:
Max{25%×Midterm+65%×Final,12.5%xMidterm+77.5%×Final}+10%×HW
reviews.comment_workload:
5-6 Assignments
1 Midterm
1 Final
No Participation required

reviews.author: Couch Potato
reviews.title: Content is okay but teaching is not......
reviews.comment_content:
This is a compulsory course for students in OM major.  Mainly about using Excel to solve different problems.  Content is not difficult if you attend all lectures and practice using Excel.  I will put the titles of chapters here.  

Ch 1, 2:  Introduction to spreadsheet modeling
Ch 3: Introduction to optimization modeling
Ch 4: Linear Programming
Ch 5: Network models
Ch 6: Optimization models with integer variables
Ch 7: Nonlinear optimization models
reviews.comment_teaching: OMG..... This is rude to say so, but the teaching is toooo boring!!!!! If I had to summarize his teaching in one sentence, I strongly recommend people who are suffering from insomnia to enroll in this course ASAP.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final exam has a large weighting on the grade.  Basically if you screw up in the final exam, your grade screws up too.  On the other hand, good performance in the final exam can help you catch up if you didn't perform well in midterm.  

Online Homework: 10%
Midterm: 25%; Final examination: 65%;
Bonus (based on your class participation): 3%
Final course scores: Max{25%×Midterm+65%×Final, 12.5%xMidterm+77.5%×Final}+10%×HW
reviews.comment_workload:
5-6 online homework, 1 midterm and 1 final.
In my opinion, workload is not big and depends on your understanding of the questions and how familiar you are with using Excel.

reviews.author: Jenyyyyyy
reviews.comment_content: Overall is to teach how to use Excel Solver to solve different problems under different situation.
reviews.comment_teaching: He spoke very slowly which he could only explain 2 problems in 1 lesson and had unclear powerpoint. Sometimes he looked like he does not know what was happening. He even asked who is good at excel during lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal.
In the beginning, midterm was counted in the grading. But he found that the mark differences were quite large. Then, there were 2 options for grading, include both midterm and final or only final, depends on your marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively low workload for 4cred course. 5 assignments which require you to fill in the answer and attach the excel file in Canvas quiz. Some of them were time-consuming because only rely on what he taught in class was totally not enough. You need to google the questions and try to answer them by modifying your own solver model and cannot copy directly.

For midterm and final, you could bring cheatsheet and notes. For true and false questions, try to mark down some important concepts. For others, some of thems are similar to the chapter exercises. You could use them to practise.

reviews.author: vixxf6
reviews.title: Boring lesson but good grade
reviews.comment_content: Please see others' comments.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring... He used a very slow tone. But I would say what he taught is very useful. So I forced myself to go. I suggest students who go to his lesson can do some exercise at home first. If you find it difficult, then you should go to his lesson. Otherwise, just stay home or go to the tutorials. BTW, his TAs' lessons are boring as Professor's.
reviews.comment_grading: Many people do not do well in the midterm so he changed the grading system (only homework 10% and the final exam 90%). This is a big relief to me since I did shit in the midterm. Luckily, I got an average score in the final exam so I got a B in the final grade. The grading is quite okay.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that heavy. But I suggest doing the homework with friends because some questions are demanding. They may take you a day to finish it. Please don't start doing it the day before the deadline, unless you have good friends who can finish the homework for you.

reviews.author: 123gg
reviews.title: Choose this course in another semester if NG SHU MING is teaching
reviews.comment_content:
The content is generally useful.
Basic use of Excel, solver. The homework and course content is quite easy in general.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This professor is simply incompetent to teach this course. He isn't even familiar with the new excel software and encountered so many technical difficulties.
During one lesson, he even asked us 'who is good in excel', this sentence is self explanatory on his teaching and computer skills.
He is very slow in lesson (might be because of his age), he speaks slow, teaches slow, it's like being in slow motion in lessons.
(p.s. I wondered every lesson why is he still teaching despite his age, he should consider retiring)

If you don't really care about learning and just want to get good grade, he's fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty good for this course, the professor made adjustments when the class did poorly in midterm. The final exams were just questions from texbook...

In most people's case, it's
10% assignment
90% final exam

If you performed better in midterm than final exam, it's
10% assignment
25% midterm
75% final exam
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload, doesn't seem like a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: Rajitha
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 2: Intro to Spreadsheet modeling
Chapter 3: Intro to optimization Modelling
Chapter 4: Linear Programming Models
Chapter 5: Network Models
Chapter 6: Optimization Models with Integer Variables
Chapter 7: Non-Linear Optimization Models -- didn't teach as we ran out of time at the end of the semester.
Other concepts: Pivot Tables
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite poor. He's quite old, comes into class 5-10 mins late, takes another couple mins to set up his computer. He speaks rather slow as well. His lectures are filmed, but watching the lecture videos can be quite boring unless you watch at 2x speed.
reviews.comment_grading:
One midterm and one final - both open notes/book - has to be hard copies. you'll get access to lecture slides, lecture examples and tutorial examples and a pdf of the textbook on K or Y Drive on the computers.

marking original scheme
Homework - 10%
Midterm - 25%
Final - 65%

but a lot of people didn't do well during midterm - so he introduced an alternative marking scheme
Homework - 10%
Final - 90%
- midterm is disregarded.
the max of both schemes will be your score basically.
Midterm - mean = 50
final - mean = 70, SD about 17.

To do decent/well in the exams, just do as many textbook questions as you can. the short answer/true or false questions are legit, just copied from the textbook, and the modeling questions are often an extension on the textbook ones as well.

TA's grade the exams, not too harsh. If you explain yourself strongly, they find it reasonable then there are chances of grade changes - but not always guaranteed.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload except the online excel homework for each chapter. you will be given a week to do them. Questions will be released on canvas, and you have to submit the excel files.
The homework questions contain 2-3 easy/moderate level of difficulty  - and then one huge case study. the case study question may take up a lot of time.
- can even find some answers to the questions online.

the homework questions are basically from the textbook. If you buy the textbook, you can access the solution bank through the access code - if not, Chegg seems to have most of the answers too.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Useful and practical applications of Excel
reviews.comment_content:
A useful course on spreadsheet modeling with Microsoft Excel. We're first introduced with basic Excel tools formulae and tools such as VLOOKUP, PivotTable and Data Table. It then moves to building spreadsheet models for different business scenarios. A significant proportion of the course (Chapters 3 - 7) focuses on optimization modeling with Solver. The problem-solving approach of this course is really great. It allows us to learn not just the Excel features, but also the way to model and solve various business problems.

Topics included:
1️⃣ Introduction to Management Science
2️⃣ Introduction to Spreadsheet Modeling
3️⃣ Introduction to Optimization Modeling
4️⃣ Linear Programming Models
5️⃣ Network Models
6️⃣ Optimization Models with Integer Variables
7️⃣ Nonlinear Optimization Models
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof ZHENG has a mild mainland accent, but this does not really affect our understanding. His pace of speech is perfect and we can easily follow his teaching. He's also a responsible instructor, willing to reply emails and answer our inquiries within a short period of time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment Scheme:
💻 20% In-class quiz
💻 10% Assignments
💻 64% Final exam
🏫 6% Class attendance
💬 +5% Bonus for class participation/discussion

I got 95/100 in the quiz (mean = 89.2), 92/100 in the final (mean = 75.2), full marks in the assignments and class attendance.

💯 Final grade: A

Fair enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are a total of 3 assignments on business cases extracted from the textbook. We're required to form groups of 1 to 3, and answer the questions by building Excel spreadsheet models from scratch. The business cases are not easy and we deffo need to spend some time on them. But this is reasonable considering that it's a 4-credit course.

Both the quiz and the final are computer-based exams similar to the exercises done in class in terms of format. The quiz covers chapters 2 to 3, while the final covers chapters 3 to 7. Open books, open notes, and we're provided with the PowerPoint slides. Make sure you prepare well for the final as it's more difficult, and it takes a huge chunk of your grade. Pay special attention to the tricks of how to transform a nonlinear model to a linear model.

reviews.author: hebearmy
reviews.title: Strongly recommend! Easy and Useful Excel Course
reviews.comment_content:
Excel applications
How to solve simple business questions in excel, e.g. staff scheduling, currency exchange, transportation, supply chain management, pricing and profit maximization, simulation, financial planning and so on
Most problems use linear solver, nonlinear GRG and evolutionary solver are also covered.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Take class in lab, with excel on all the time, so it is pretty solution-oriented.
Professor Zhang is very nice and helpful.
It interesting to attend his class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 15% *3
FInal 55%

Quizes are 2 to 3 questions in excel file. The questions are straightforward, mainly in-class examples. Most people get full marks, I guess.
Final have 6 more complicated questions. You really need to be careful, or you will make unexpected mistakes like me xD( I thought I'd get full marks, but the result is not even close...)
Cheatsheets are always allowed.

I got full marks in all three quizes, around 1SD over mean in Final (SD is not provided, I asked TA though), my grade is A
reviews.comment_workload:
The most light and gentle course I have ever taken in UST!!!
Can't believe it is a four-credit course! Feel like a two-cre!
No group project, no assignment, no participation
还有谁！

reviews.author: 連登仔
reviews.title: 多謝Professor，以後我會好好做人，呢個post係寫黎吹奏你既
reviews.comment_content: Excel functions and linear programming
reviews.comment_teaching: Great, light accent, clear explanation
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 20% (Ch1- Part of Ch3)
Attendance: 6% (take 5 times, get 4 for full)
HW: 10% (3 times)
Final: 64% (Ch3 - Ch7)

Most of us get full mark or nearly full mark in midterm, attendence and HW, so your grade depends only on final.

Final data:
From the graph, >25% people get full mark, mean: 83.4, median must be higher than that, about 85-88. Which means if you did it wrong for one question(about 16%) in final, you are done.

But I think the grading is quite good, overall 92%, I got an A. Maybe this course uses absolute grading.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 HW assignments about cases on textbook,  quite hard, but you can do them in group of 3.

reviews.author: Rachel_Phineas
reviews.comment_content: It's one of my favorite course in UST. It includes practical usage of Excel and methodologies of solving business problems by cool combinations of functions. If you like the magic of seeing problems solved after a few click, it's for you!
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has my high regard. He's very patient, gentle and approachable. He is never bothered by any questions in class. And he'll be glad to answer after class as well.

Speed of talking- perfect
reviews.comment_grading: I'm not sure about the curve but I got A. All I did was paying attention to the lectures, do the practice exercise regularly and more exercises from the textbook before exams.
reviews.comment_workload: Being a 4-credit course, I think the work load is fair enough, pretty much like that of a 3-credit course to me.

reviews.author: JonSnow
reviews.title: WORST TA'S EVER!
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting content. Learning about optimizing routes to take, or number of employees to hire. Very logical, so it was quite fun.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is amazing. He has a very hands on approach and gives you chance to ask questions. Very easy to understand, and makes the class quite fun. HOWEVER, the TA's were so bad! I stopped going to the tutorials because you could not understand the TA's at all. The female TA, Ms. Xinli Xie, spoke so softly and with terrible english that I wanted to kill myself in every tutorial I went. Honestly, she should have been removed because she was of no help. Even the male TA, Mr. Haoyu Liu, spoke in a monotonous tone which made it very hard to understand. The TA's should have been fired because they sucked.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was fair. I performed well in the three quizzes, but got below mean in final exam but still got a B. So i was satisfied.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically no workload. Only 3 quizzes and a final exam.
Each quiz 15% and if you dont take it, you can move the weight to the final exam. Final exam worth 55%. No homework or anything.

reviews.author: kky
reviews.comment_content: Very useful content as this course teaches a lot of excel skills that might be useful in your intern. It only covers 6 chapters.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Zheng is very friendly. If you ask him questions, he is willing to answer. Yet, sometimes the speed for his demonstration for using Excel is quite fast. Usually, he starts the demo slow at the beginning of the class, and get faster and faster when the examples are getting more challenging. Pay attention in class. Otherwise, if you miss one step, you may be completely lost in the remaining of the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz and exam are open-book, open notes. Quizzes are simple. As long as you print out all the in-class exercises, you will be fine. There are 4-5 questions for the quizzes and exam. The questions in the exam are slightly harder. Since many people score high marks on quizzes and exams, it means you need to score above 90% to get an A.

5 attendance will be taken throughout the semester. If you attend more than 3 times, you will score full mark for the attendance.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. Only 2 quizzes and 1 final.

reviews.author: Tszyeungyeung
reviews.comment_content: The course include a lot of practical skills in Excel. It will teach you how to use slover, slover table, pivot table, and some useful modeling skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: Each lesson the instructor would have some example problem to demonstrate the skills. The instructor teach very slowly, it would give you plenty of time to try solving the problem, then it would solve it himself and show the most effective way.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1 (in-class): 20%
Quiz 2 (in-class): 20%
Final examination: 55%
All open book.
Class Attendance: 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
Very minimal.
There are option homework for you to practice the skills he taught. But you can skip them if you already fully understand what he teach during lesson. All you need to do is to prepare for the quiz and exam.
Skipped all tutorial... don't know what it is about.(still A)

reviews.author: hiu
reviews.comment_content:
This course is very practical. We learn in class mainly by doing examples. The lecture is like an Excel lab. Topics such as breakeven analysis, product mix, investment plan and shipping plan (in order to minimise costs and maximise profits, etc.) are discussed. Lecture notes (in ppt format) and exercises are provided. Attendance is taken for 5 times and you can get full mark for this part if you don't miss more than twice.

Ch 2: Introduction to spreadsheet modeling  Ch 3: Introduction to optimization modeling  Ch 4: Linear Programming models
Ch 5: Network models
Ch 6: Optimization models with integer variables
Ch 7: Nonlinear optimization models
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is fast, as you may need to listen to the explanations while doing the examples. The professor tried to ask questions to make us more involved, but sometimes no one could follow and respond.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1 (in-class): 20%
Quiz 2 (in-class): 20%
Final examination: 55%
Class Attendance: 5%
Bonus point for class participation/discussion: up to 5%
(Even if you don't speak up in class at all, you may still get an A.)
reviews.comment_workload: We don't need to hand in the homework exercises given. They are just for our own practice, though the complicated ones may be discussed in class.

reviews.author: ThePostman
reviews.comment_content: The content discussed in the course is extremely useful when working for companies. It presents essentials of Excel such as Pivot Tables or Linear programming which one would probably not really know in-depth otherwise.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade is normal. Not good grade or bad grade in any way.
reviews.comment_workload: The key to getting a good grade in this course is to practice as much as possible the different problems offered in then textbook. In the final exam, you will have to create the excel files yourself without any template to help you.

reviews.author: khwongaz
reviews.comment_content:
Quite practical.
Basic excel course with many useful functions taught.
Mostly focus on solving linear and non -linear problems using Solver.
For example, some integer linear problems, networking logistic problems. They are quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A bit dull.
Fast when he demonstrates his examples during class. You need to pay attention, if not, you will be lost.
So don't be afraid to ask questions because if no questions raised, he will think you guys are ok with that and started to talk a lot more faster.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1     20%
Quiz 2     20%
Final       55%
Participation   5%

Quiz 1 and 2 are straight forward and easy, the mean is around 90%.
But final is more difficult, the mean is around 84%.
Participation will be recorded in class.

Overall I got 94% and that's an A-. That's not bad but need to work hard because the mean is very high.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically very light workload.
Only 2 quiz and a final.

Quiz's question is similar with those on your powerpoint.
All you have to do is practice more for your final.

All quiz and final are open books and notes.

reviews.author: Annabelle
reviews.comment_content: Basically a course on how to use Excel to solve problems. Teaches how to use Solver and SolverTable. The material is very useful, but gets hard towards the end. Mainly covers linear programming and some integer programming. The professor talks about business applications in class. He said he had several students who took his course, and after graduation, came back and told him how useful the material is at work.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ok la. Professor teaches quite slowly.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is very good. There is one midterm exam and one final. One warning about the exams though: the computers could malfunction! So make sure to start the computer and try everything before the exam starts.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate. There are several online quizzes and you get two chances to get the right answers.

reviews.author: cwwwww
reviews.title: Buy the Textbook and you can skip the class
reviews.comment_content: Guiding students to use excel and solver to solve some problems, mainly linear equation. Usually those problems are related to our live, say resources allocation. The course is quite practical to students. If you are good at excel or you have bought the textbook, you don't have to go to the class actually.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor speak very clear, not very fast and make sure you can follow him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade:)
But the mean is quite high. The mean of quiz is always >90%. The questions are straight forward, just try to be careful.
reviews.comment_workload: there are two quiz worth 20% each, the final is 60%. Open Book and Notes. Professors will choose 6 to 7 questions from the textbook to be homework, but just for self practice, no need to submit.

reviews.author: scrappo
reviews.title: Excel Course - only take if you are interested in learning excel, but still not worth imo (adv excel users should avoid)
reviews.comment_content:
The course content is fine, but pretty simple stuff. Felt like i didnt learn that much after 1.5 months.

In addition, its all in excel so not anything too innovative going on.

I would recommend against taking this course only because i think its not very applicable for anything outside the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Hongtao is actually pretty cool and makes some criminally underrated jokes in class
reviews.comment_grading: Quizzes are pretty easy but in my opinion the final was much more difficult than i expected.
reviews.comment_workload: barely any workload but if u want to do well on exams should follow the recommended hw assignments
